 ARGENTINA SOCIAL PROTECTION PROJECT 1. SOCIAL ISSUES IN ARGENTINA A. Economic Setting' 1.1 Four years have passed since Argentina, emerging from the severe economic crisis of 1989-90, adopted the Convertibility Plan. This innovative plan restructured Argentina's economic landscape through reforms of the state and financial institutions, privatization, and liberalization of foreign and domestic credit. From extreme hyper- inflation, the country moved relatively quickly to a low annual inflation rate of 3.9 percent in 1994. Output and productivity increases have been remarkable for the last four years, with GDP growth averaging 7.7 percent annually. The initial consumption- led boom matured into a healthy pattern of investment and export-led growth. Privatization of state assets has been far-reaching, and much more successful than expected. As a result of the economic recovery, poverty levels declined significantly, although economic restructuring with a rigid labor market has resulted in increased unemployment, which reached about 13 percent of the labor force by late 1994. 1.2 With the dynamic evolution of the economy, shifting from consumption to export and investment-led growth, GDP in 1993 and 1994 grew by 6 and 7.1 percent respectively. Gross fixed investment reached 20 percent in 1994, associated with increased national and foreign savings. Exports, which were affected by declining international prices in 1992-93, rose by 20 percent in 1994, with manufactured goods exports exhibiting particular buoyancy, growing at an average of 27 percent in 1993-94. Better international prices for grains and improved economic conditions in Brazil contributed to the growth in exports. Imports of capital goods led the expansion, indicative of the acceleration in investment and the restructuring of the economy. Financing trade and current account deficits was not difficult, given Argentina's improved access to international financial markets during 1993 and 1994. During the first two months of 1995, exports rose by 35 percent, while imports remained approximately at the previous year's level. l See the Country Assistance Strategy dated April 10, 1995 for a more comprehensive assessment of Argentina's economic prospects.

The Mexico Crisis and Its Inpact on Argentina 1.3 Despite these achievements, Argentina is now facing its first serious financial crisis since the implementation of the Convertibility Plan in 1991. The country has been particularly vulnerable to the events in Mexico, due to Argentina's relatively heavy reliance on foreign capital inflows (financing in 1994 an estimated current account deficit of 3.6 percent of GDP), the inflexibility of its exchange rate regime, and the need for a strong financial system under the Convertibility Plan. Higher international interest rates and the Mexico crisis have reduced capital inflows. From December 1994 through March 1995, the stock market declined by about 30 percent and banking deposits fell by about 15 percent. Consequently, economic activity has slowed considerably, with economic growth during 1995 expected to be flat. 1.4 In mid-March 1995, the Government reacted forcefully to mitigate the crisis. To reestablish a fiscal surplus, it cut expenditures on export subsidies, public sector wages, social security expenditures, and federally-funded social services, while raising the VAT rate and other taxes. The Government extended to March 31, 1996 its program with the International Monetary Fund, (IMF) and announced that tax adjustments would generate a fiscal surplus of 1.4 percent of GDP (including privatization proceeds) in 1995. The announced measures are estimated to yield US$6.3 billion, equivalent to 2 percent of GDP, in the remainder of 1995. At the same time, public expenditures were cut by 3.6 percent in comparison with the original budget approved in December 1994. This decline is expected to result in a contraction in public sector wages, investment, and non-wage recurrent spending for a large number of federal programs, including social services (see below). 1.5 The Government is reinvigorating the adjustment process by passing legislation capping social security pensions, liberalizing labor laws to small and medium enterprises, and taking measures to restructure the financial system by accelerating the privatization of provincial banks and the consolidation of private banks. To bolster its adjustment program, the Government has assembled a financial package of approximately US$11 billion from multilateral organizations (US$5.4 billion from IMF, the Bank and Inter-American Development Bank, IDB), the Japanese EXIM Bank (US$0.8 billion), bond sales (US$2.3 billion) and projected asset sales (US$2.4 billion). 1.6 The strong and rapid reaction of the Government to the crisis has reduced concerns about its future domestic action but the external environment remains uncertain. Although the initially strong negative reaction of financial markets to the Mexican crisis has now improved, there remains a reluctance to redirect significant flows towards emerging markets, particularly in Latin America. Even under an optimistic scenario, in which the principal countries affected by the crisis adopt
 3 appropriate economic policy measures that reestablish credibility in the eyes of international investors in the next few months, access to international financial markets would be only slowly regained beginning in late 1995, and capital inflows would remain below those observed in previous years. C. Argentina's Poverty and Unemployment Situation 1.7 The general slowdown in economic activity, the rise in unemployment, and the recent reduction of public expenditures could have adverse effects on social conditions. A risk exists that the country's poverty situation, which has improved substantially since 1989, could deteriorate under these circumstances. 1.8 Argentina's poverty level2 declined significantly between 1990 and 1993. During that time, the share of the population living in poverty fell from about 35 percent to 20 percent. In Metropolitan Buenos Aires (MBA), where more than a third of the country's population lives, the 1993 poverty rate (the proportion of the population below an estimated poverty line) was 17.6 percent, or almost half its 1990 level. Not only did poverty in MBA greatly diminish in the 1990s, but the poor as a group did not experience as much extreme poverty as in the past. 1.9 Notwithstanding these improvements, poverty remains a reality for a sizable part of the population. Even though lack of reliable data on rural poverty continues to be a problem, some limited information based on case studies, qualitative assessments and surveys points to acute poverty in rural areas. The highest rates of poverty -- averaging 40 percent -- occur in the provinces in the Northeast and Northwest of the country. The rate of poverty decline in the early 1990s has been much swifter in MBA than in the remote provinces. While all provincial cities have experienced a fall in poverty between 1990 and 1992, the speed of decline has been slowest in the northern provinces. As a result, the share of the nation's poor living in the north has risen from 24 percent to 29 percent. 1.10 Rising unemployment has become a major concern in Argentina, in part because it exacerbates the country's poverty situation (in 1993, more than 25 percent of the unemployed population in MBA were living below the poverty line). Despite the impressive growth performance of the Argentine economy during 1990-94, the number of net jobs created was only around 350,000 or a 3.1 percent cumulative increase for the four-year period. Most of this growth took place in 1991-1992. In 1993 there was no employment growth, and in 1994 there was a net decrease of about 1.5 percent. I By March 1996 1.17 The adjusted 1995 federal social budget of US$27.2 billion includes social insurance (US$19.2 billion) and traditional programs "targeted" to the poor (US$3.8 billion) and of a more "universal" nature (US$4.3 billion). Even after taking into account the announced budget cuts, the changes in spending between 1994 and 1995 vary substantially among these three categories -- a real decline of 4.1 percent for social insurance and real increases of 2 percent for universal programs and of 38 percent for the targeted programs. In other words, despite the fact that the social programs directed to the poor have been cut in 1995 about the same amount as the rest of the federal budget, planned spending for these poverty programs is still more than one-third higher than in the previous year of 1994. This is because the current system of obligatory and automatic national revenue transfers to the provinces (co-participation), and the financing of other programs such as social security and interest on public debt that are difficult or impossible to cut, leave the Government with a narrow base of a little more than a fifth of the total budget from which any or all cuts would have to occur. Under these circumstances, it is critical that the Government protect and increase the efficiency of its spending for health, nutrition, education, rural development, and employment and income support programs targeted to the poor. E. Govermment Social Policy and Strategy 1.19 The Government's letter of social policy dated October 10, 1995 (Annex 1) argues that the intensification of economic growth and the maintenance of stability would strengthen overall social conditions in the country. The Government intends to attach high priority to the development of policies to create new employment opportunities and to invest in human resources (through education, training, and health services) to prepare people for a competitive labor market. 1.20 To fight against unemployment, the Government is implementing a very comprehensive policy. First, the Government is setting measures to improve the functioning of the labor market: (i) the Law on contracts (Ley de Modalidades de Contratacion, passed in March 1995) prescribes a three month probationary period for apprenticeship contracts and streamlines part-time work; (ii) the Law on small and medium enterprises (Ley de PYMES passed in March 1995) provides more flexibility over contractual modes, labor practices and provides separate considerations for collective bargaining agreements; (iii) the Compensation Insurance Law (Ley de Riesgos de Trabajo submitted to the Congress) would reduce the costs supported by the wages; (iv) the Law on bankruptcy (Ley de Quiebras submitted to the Congress) would consolidate the economic restructuring process and subsequent sectoral shifts; and (v) a law to modify the actual system of labor negotiations and labor contracts will be sent to Congress. Second, the Government announced in August 1995 a package of measures to increase employment and fiscal revenues: (i) a reduction of labor taxes will be done progressively between September 1995 and January 1996, reducing the cost of labor by about 7.5 percent in Buenos Aires to 20 percent in provinces like Chaco, Formosa and Santiago de Estero; (ii) workers with salaries above $2000 per month will not receive family allowances and the money saved will be deposited in a special fund for emergencies and training for low income workers; (iii) enterprises that hire workers over 55 years of age will be exempted from all labor taxes and contributions for these workers; and (iv) the minimum age for employment, which at the present time is 14
 9 years, would be increased and education or training for all the population below the minimum age would be guaranteed. 1.21 To improve the quality and efficiency of spending for the social sectors, the Government has sought the assistance of the World Bank. Major projects to strengthen primary, secondary, and higher education have recently begun or are about to be finalized. The recently effective Decentralization and Improvement of Secondary Education Project (Ln.3794-AR) will strengthen the central education ministry and seven provincial ministries. The Higher Education Reform Project (Ln. 3794-AR), which has already been approved, will support a series of efficiency-enhancing measures, including increased financial autonomy for universities, an accreditation and evaluation system for public and private institutions, and a more transparent financial mechanism for allocating federal resources to Argentine universities. 1.22 Similarly, important initiatives are being carried out for the health sector. The ongoing Maternal and Child Health and Nutntion Project (Ln. 3643-AR) is targeting poor mothers and young children in the urban poverty belts and the underdeveloped northern provinces. A recently approved Provincial Health Development Project (Ln 3931-AR) will transform public hospitals into independent trusts, strengthen the management systems, develop hospital accreditation, and test new hospital reimbursement practices. To enhance the efficiency of the more than 3 percent of GDP spent through the Argentine health insurance system, the Government is planning to undertake a reform program, with the help of a World Bank loan. 1.23 The development and implementation of an effective social policy is severely constrained by the paucity of information and of appropriate systems to target, monitor and evaluate social development actions, especially those meant to benefit the poor. The Federal Government, through the Secretaria de Desarrollo Social (SDS), is spearheading the development of targeting approaches for social programs and the monitoring and evaluation of resulting actions. More specifically, SDS is launching a program called SIEMPRO (Sistema de Informaci6n, Evaluaci6n y Monitoreo de Programas Sociales) that would establish the information system to help improve social program management in Argentina. With SIEMPRO's assistance, corresponding capacity in poverty monitoring and targeting, evaluation and monitoring of social programs would be developed in the provinces, which are now primarily responsible for delivering social services. The Government is also encouraging the participation of non-governmental and community-based organizations in programs specifically directed to the extreme poor to complement weak public service delivery.

Rationale for Bank Involvement 2.1 The proposed loan is fully consistent with the Bank's Country Assistance Strategy which was presented to the Board on May 4, 1995, with the Provincial Bank Privatization project (Ln. 3878-AR). The strategy focuses on supporting Argentina's efforts to: (a) consolidate and deepen structural reforms, with strong support during the 1995 crisis period; (b) reduce poverty and develop human resources; and (c) rebuild the country's deteriorated infrastructure base. The proposed loan for the Social Protection Project, part of a US$1.3 billion emergency package offered by the Bank to Argentina (and including operations to reform the banking and health insurance sectors), would help safeguard the delivery of critical social services to the poor and those most adversely affected by the current economic crisis, particularly the unemployed, and improve the efficiency of social expenditures. Thus, the proposed project would support objective (b), related to poverty reduction and human resources development. 2.2 The Bank is already contributing substantial resources to improving the quality, efficiency and effectiveness of social services in Argentina through a set of lending operations in education and health, plus a health financing study and a recent poverty assessment. In addition the Bank produced a background report entitled "Labor Market and Institutions" for the Argentina Country Economic Memorandum (CEM) which provides an analysis of the employment situation, a description of recent labor policy reforms, and orientations for future governmental action. Through these activities, the Bank has developed sector knowledge and strong ties with social sector agencies that enable it to play a unique role in assisting Argentina during the current economic crisis. B. The Role of Other Donors 2.3 The IDB has recently approved a US$450 million Social Sector Adjustment Loan, designed to disburse in three tranches between July 1995 and June 1996. The IDB and the Bank have worked closely together, both in Washington and in the field, to ensure consistency in the operational design and conditionalities of their respective operations. The key conditionality in the IDB operation relates to maintaining for 1995 at least 85 percent of the planned federal expenditure of US$1.039 million for a broad "basket" of 23 targeted social programs. This is complemented by the proposed condition in the Social Protection Project that the Government achieve at least 100 percent of planned 1995 spending for key social programs (within the basket of 23 programs) in the areas of employment, education, health and nutrition. To ensure that federal social spending is rationalized over the coming years, the World Bank project contains a conditionality that the Government carry out a public social expenditure
 11 review. The Bank's project finances a major effort to build capacity to evaluate social programs and improve their design and management. 2.4 There is strong complementarity between the IDB and World Bank operations at the individual sector and program level. IDB's support for a national nutrition plan and for improvements in the Ministry of Health's maternal and child health care program are matched by World Bank protection of the ASOMA nutrition program. Similarly, in the area of labor and employment, the IDB loan focuses on the implementation of new labor legislation and the development of a labor market information system, while the World Bank operation supports improvements in the design and management of public works employment programs and the development of a more effective surveillance system for unemployment insurance. C. Lessons Learned from Other Operations 2.5 There has been no previous Bank experience in Argentina with this type of project, which finances a number of existing social programs for a two year "time- slice." A similar operation - the Mexico Program of Essential Social Services (PROSSE), (Ln.3912-MX) - will be in an early implementation stage by the time the Argentina operation is ready for Bank approval. Some lessons learned from the preparation phase of the Mexico project are that: (a) it is important to identify up-front social programs that use procurement and financial accounting practices already acceptable to the Bank, to ensure that government expenditures would be eligible for Bank financing; (b) choosing a limited number of relatively large social programs greatly simplifies implementation; and (c) social expenditure conditionality should be simple, clearly monitorable, and should build in some flexibility for adjustments in the "outer" years to be agreed between the Government and the Bank. Each of these lessons has been taken into account in the proposed project. A major effort has gone into reviewing procurement and accounting practices during pre-appraisal and appraisal. In the end, only Federal Government programs in employment and education would be financed directly with the proposed loan. The expenditure conditionality would set an aggregate floor level for 1996, but would be defined in greater detail during consultations between the Argentine Government and the Bank during the last quarter of 1995. 2.6 Relevant lessons learned from Bank experience with social investment funds (SIFs) are now relatively abundant. The distinguishing characteristics of these communities are elaborated in the FOPAR Operational Manual. 3.29 In poor communities, groups have an acute lack of the most essential services and employment opportunities are scarce. However, most of these communities tend to have social networks which provide a good foundation for organizational strengthening. Support to poor communities would focus on strengthening grassroots organizations with the aim of promoting participation, and on addressing critical needs as defined by the communities themselves. Projects would be formulated by grassroots organizations and be evaluated by FOPAR on a project-by-project basis. Based on preliminary surveys undertaken by FOPAR, subprojects for these communities would tend towards construction or rehabilitation of social infrastructure, training in the management of basic social services, and creation of the capacity to identify and formulate projects suitable to community needs. 3.30 In the case of deprived neighborhoods, poverty tends to originate from a sharp decline in wages and employment, aggravated by migrations from rural areas. These areas normally show poor housing conditions and low levels of access to social services and basic infrastructure. In these neighborhoods, the starting point is to identify specifically vulnerable target groups. These communities normally have limited active social networks, because of the existence of many vulnerable groups and/or migrants from other areas. The vulnerable groups include female-headed households, children under the age of four, and unemployed young people. Given that in the provincial capitals there is a relatively large number of intermediary NGOs involved in social

In the early 1980s, the program expanded with the passage of the Chagas Law (Ley No. 22360) and receipt of institutional development assistance from the World Health Organization (WHO). The program's current objective is to eliminate over the next five years the occurrence of new cases of the disease. This would be done by: (a) controlling the vectoral transmission of the Tripanosoma Cruzi parasite using insecticide treatment of infected houses and surrounding structures; (b) screening of pregnant mothers and monitoring children whose mothers are infected; (c) quality control of blood donated to the 857 laboratories that belong to the network of the Instituto Nacional de Chagas; (d) detecting and treating infected children; (e) assisting the rural population in improving their housing (up to a cost of US$2,500 per house) in order to eradicate the insect vector for the disease; (f) carrying out entomological surveillance of inspected and treated houses with community involvement; and (g) developing biomedical and operational research necessary for the program. 6. Nutrition (Apoyo Solidario a los Mayores, or ASOMA, US$86 million or 14 percent of total cost). The Secretaria de Desarrollo Social started ASOMA in 1993, as a way of offering nutritional and health assistance to the elderly poor. The program is designed to benefit people 60 years of age or more who do not receive a pension and are at high risk of illness on account of their poor nutritional condition. Of the 4.6 million Argentines over 60 years of age, 350,000 are in need of social assistance, based on the poverty index (NBI). Of these, 144,000 are now beneficiaries of ASOMA. 10. Targeting is achieved through a poverty map which uses the poverty index (a more sensitive index for this program is currently being tested). In addition, information is provided by each potential participant through an extensive questionnaire. This indicates, health condition, physical mobility, access to income and other social services, and family circumstances. Details of the ASOMA beneficiary population are currently being computerized. In situations where there are more eligible candidates for the program than resources, the final selection of beneficiaries is made by the community. 11. For most beneficiaries, the food -- valued at US$25 a month -- is packed in a 17-kilo box of commodities designed to provide 1500 calories and 40 grams of protein a day. A small fraction of participants receive daily meals in a dining facility. Nutrition considerations are reflected in the selection of the foods. 12. ASOMA's budget resources, currently amounting to about US$43 million for 1995, are transferred to the provinces. In most cases, the provincial governments organize competitive bidding for the purchase of the food. About 15 percent of the program is handled directly by non-government organizations, primarily church-related groups. An effort is under way to expand NGO involvement in ASOMA. 13. The ASOMA staff in the Secretariat of Social Development headquarters consists of about 50 persons including 21 professionals. Half deal with planning, while the other half review proposals, organize contracts, and manage project execution. The Subsecretariat for the Elderly audits the receipts for purchases of food. 14. An agreement signed in May 1995 between ASOMA and the Instituto Nacional de Servicios Sociales Para Jubilados y Pensionados (INSSJP), which runs the Programa de Atencion Medica Integral (PAMI), should strengthen ASOMA. PAMI has successfully provided food to over 300,000 elderly persons receiving the minimum pension of 150 pesos per month. It would provide training and technical assistance to ASOMA and in some cases share its dining facilities. The collaboration would also help to eliminate any overlap between the two programs.

During the first two years of its implementation, SIEMPRO would develop a program of gradual transference, technical assistance, and training based on the information, methodologies and systems developed for targeting, monitoring and evaluation of social programs especially directed to the poor. For this purpose, an amount of about US$2.0 million would be allocated for a Technical Dissemination Plan (TDP) under the proposed project with the following specific objectives: (a) assist in the establishment of small provincial SLEMPRO units (Unidades Ejecutoras Provinciales, UEP) in the provincial Ministry of Social Action or other counterpart provincial agency which would set up the social information system and monitoring/evaluation of provincial social programs targeted to the poor; and (b) finance the monitoring and evaluation and/or other technical studies for targeted social programs with priority for those supported under Component A of the Social Protection Project. H. Operational Mechanism 2. The TDP would operate on a demand-driven basis with respect to resource transfer to the provinces (i.e. objective (a) above). A provincial Ministry of Social Action or equivalent SDS provincial counterpart agency interested in receiving financial assistance for the above objectives would need to send a letter of request (carta de adhesion) to SDS-SIEMPRO. The primary eligibility criterion to qualify a province for TDP funding would be its poverty situation as characterized by its NBI level. Provinces with more than 25% NBI would receive priority in TDP funding. In case the requesting province qualify under this basic criterion, SIEMPRO would carry out a diagnostic evaluation of the requesting provincial agency, taking into account the following factors: (i) deficiency in availability of information for poverty monitoring; (ii) absence of clear targeting criteria in the social programs of the province; (iii) absence of systematic monitoring and evaluation of social programs; and (iv) internal institutional setting and inter-institutional linkages of the requesting provincial agency. Once SIEMPRO approves its inclusion, the provincial agency would need to execute a subsidiary agreement (Convenio de Adhesion) with SIEMPRO, which would set out the conditions for the resource transfer and the supervisory arrangements between SIEMPRO and the counterpart institution. This agreement would be accompanied by a Work Plan (Plan de

doc.abstracts: The major objectives of Social Protection Project are to: 1) protect critical social programs for the poor and the vulnerable during the period of severe fiscal restraint in 1995 and 1996; 2) assist in providing income support to those who would be adversely affected by the economic measures, especially those who would lose their jobs; and 3) improve the focus and management of social programs by promoting transparency and efficiency, participation of the civil society, and better targeting of social services to the poor. The project will have three major components: 1) priority social and income support programs; 2) pilot participatory social investment fund (FOPAR); and 3) improvement of social information, targeting and monitoring of social programs (SIEMPRO).
